Title:
The Amoebophrya Genome: A parasitic dinoflagellate with a
complete transfer of mitochondrial genes into the nucleus.
Keywords:
dinoflagellates, mitochondrial genome loss, tryptophan
synthesis regulation, parasite genome, evolution
Abstract:
Dinoflagellates are highly enigmatic organisms that
display a number of unusual lifestyle characteristics. Dinoflagellate
genomic features are also exceptional, and large genome sizes and
unusual DNA packaging are commonly observed. Organellar genomes are
typically found in small amplified pieces as a consequence of the
transfer of most organellar genes to the nucleus. This group of
organisms is abundant and globally distributed and therefore has a major
impact on the environment. In this study, the relatively small genome of
Amoebophrya, which is a parasite of other dinoflagellates, was sequenced
to further investigate the genomic features of dinoflagellates and
parasitic organisms. Several parasitic features were observed in the
genome, such as the lack of a complete TCA cycle and an inability to
generate certain amino acids. Notably, tryptophan synthesis was
physically interlocked at the genetic level with the shikimate pathway,
thus constituting a novel type of metabolic regulation. Although
mitochondria are observed in Amoebophrya at certain life stages, no
traces of a mitochondrial genome were found. Genes that were retained on
minimal mitochondrial genomes in other species were transferred to the
nucleus in Amoebophrya, making this the first species to exhibit loss of
the mitochondrial genome.
This analysis of the Amoebophrya genome provides comprehensive data for
further studies and contributes substantially to the comprehension of
Alveolata and dinoflagellate evolution.
